column2: AI can replace many jobs, such as in the accounting industry, where some simple calculations no longer require human intervention. I also use AI in my daily life, but I am careful about personal privacy when using it, as I worry about potential exposure of my private information. AI has been very helpful in my life—for example, I just consulted AI for the steps to update my R version.  In learning, I am not concerned that AI might create unfair competition among classmates because their grades have nothing to do with me. I only need to focus on my own performance. AI can help us solve unexpected challenges, but it should not replace our thinking. I believe AI is a great tool.

genai: A Few,A Few,Neutral,Disagree,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Strongly Agree,Agree,Neutral,Strongly Agree,Disagree,Neutral,Agree
column2:
From my view, I believe using AI tools is a complex situation. First of all, we have to admit that AI tools are taking an increasingly huge part of our life as they are developing incredibly, in some fields, especially in the design and coding field, my colleagues and friends said the AI tools did help them a lot with their jobs. Yet as the regulations and laws about AI are still at the early phase, using AI ethically is mostly depends on the individual's moral standard, thus I believe using AI requires a specific rule or at least there should be a line to declare the AI can be used in which situation or level.

For myself, I haven't used AI that much, and I only used it to prepare for my interviews, like searching for information of some specific things.

genai: A Few,A Few,Disagree,Disagree,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Disagree,Neutral,Disagree,Agree,Disagree,Agree,Agree
column2:
I used to use AI to generate paintings.

Overall, the results were pretty much what I wanted, but there were always some parts that weren't as good as I could have been, even though I described the prompts in a clear and detailed way. This requires me to make my own changes based on the results it generates.

So my point is that generative AI can save time and increase efficiency for practitioners. But if you need AI-generated content that is beyond your ability level, and you can't verify and modify the results, the results will often be unsatisfactory.

While I look forward to the day when generative AI will be able to produce exactly what I expected and don't need to be modified, I still feel anxious and worried about it if I can't verify it.

genai: Some,Many,Agree,Disagree,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Agree,Disagree,Neutral,Agree,Strongly Disagree,Agree,Strongly Agree
column2:
GenAI is a great tool in the learning process, it should be used to strength your already existing knowledge but you should never get it create anything that is FOREIGN to you. AI is a great tool to dump all your curiosities and deep opinions onto regarding a topic, use it to understand a subject in greater depth, but having it do all the work for you feels dangerous and most importantly ungratifying. 

 

In my opinion, the controversy behind LLMs and other AIs is rather blown out of proportion, if people use it to do all their assignments for them it should be EASILY detectable for any marker/instructor, there should be no difference between using an AI generator and having a semi-reliable online tutor, that can help you steer your work in the right direction and help you understand concepts that otherwise would be too difficult to grasp by one's self.

genai: A Few,Some,Agree,Strongly Agree,Always allowed,Strongly Agree,Agree,Disagree,Strongly Disagree,Disagree,Strongly Disagree,Neutral,Agree
column2: GenAI’s kinda like a double-edged sword for jobs—it’ll probably handle grunt work like data crunching, but human skills like creativity or empathy will stay in demand. Ethically? Yikes—hidden biases in training data and copyright gray zones worry me, not to mention companies quietly replacing roles with bots. As for peers, some treat ChatGPT like a homework vending machine (copy-paste essays = bad news), and over-reliance on AI coding tools risks turning us into debug-illiterates. Learning-wise, it’s turbocharged research (Perplexity’s my go-to), but I’ve caught myself skimming surfaces instead of diving deep. Personally, I’ve hacked deadlines with Midjourney for posters and Claude for digesting dense reports, though I always fact-check—AI’s the shortcut, but my brain’s still the GPS!

genai: A Few,A Few,Disagree,Disagree,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Agree,Agree,Agree,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Strongly Agree
column2:
I think that GenAI tools will definitely make a place for itself in various fields (i.e research, medical applications, etc) but it definitely poses as a concern for me since there's still much to be learnt about AI. It would great if it meant that manpower could be concentrated or reorganised into areas where we need human thinking the most, but only time will tell!

I do think that GenAI should be thoroughly discussed and incorporated into learning environments since it appears that it will be sticking around for the long run. That way, more people will be made aware of its potential uses/misuses, ethical complications (e.g malicious intent?!, or even art generating models trained using art without permissions) and how we should handle GenAI in the future.

(In case the quiz timer seemed long, I was attacked by a cockroach mid-quiz)

genai: A Few,Some,Neutral,Neutral,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Agree,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Agree,Neutral
Some,Some,Disagree,Agree,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Agree,Disagree,Disagree,Neutral,Disagree,Agree,Neutral
column2:
I think AI has the potential to undermine genuine effort in certain circumstances. However, it is not a replacement for understanding a topic and therefore someone reliant on it for their work is likely to run into trouble fairly quickly. 

I have found it very useful as a learning tool especially when summarising large quantities of notes or as a study tool (creating potential essay questions etc).

I have also found it very useful for debugging code/suggesting better ways of writing the code, allowing me to continue to learn without constantly having to go to someone more knowledgeable.

column2: I think GenAI has been quite helpful for me. If it has been used I think it is important that it should be included in the references section of the assignment, including what section it has been applied to, to ensure that students are not taking credit for a section that they have not done completely by themselves. I have also made sure to know what the rules lecturers have around the use of GenAI is, as some can be more open to its use compared to others.

genai: Some,A Few,Disagree,Neutral,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Agree,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Strongly Disagree,Disagree,Strongly Disagree
column2: Although I have not been using Gen AI to assist with my learning, I do think it can be useful in helping students to better understand course content. I have seen my fellow peers use this to improve their understanding of course contents (such as technical differences between similar terms), as well as gaining an understanding of why their code doesn't work, or why the code works a certain way etc.

genai: Some,Some,Agree,Neutral,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Agree,Disagree,Disagree,Agree,Agree,Agree,Agree

A Few,A Few,Neutral,Neutral,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Strongly Agree,Neutral,Disagree,Neutral,Disagree,Neutral,Agree,Neutral
column2:
I have been using Grammarly (to my understanding, it's also a generative AI), and whenever it suggests any improvements or improves my writing, I am trying to learn how it's restructuring, or at least trying to learn bits from it.

Regarding other Gen AI like Chat GPT or Copliot, I haven't used it much for my academic purpose; I mostly use it for personal purposes.

Reg academically, I use it to understand some topics that were new to me and reg coding, I have used it to understand existing codes and to search syntax for specific algorithms but not for generating a large chunk of code. I do not see any point in using a code that I myself won't understand.

(Of course, all these were done during my work, not during my academic years; I haven't done much of coding from an academic perspective), There was one course where I had to do a bit of coding, but in that course, the use of AI was permitted as long as we understood the codes and provided comments on our reasoning for using that particular code. I feel that, in those scenarios, AI was used like a colleague who would help us out when we were stuck somewhere.

But I would not accept if someone uses the large chunk of code from AI without understanding (mostly, it's not going to be helpful for them), and most of the time, the code that it generates will not be the solution for our problem.

genai: Some,Some,Agree,Disagree,Always disallowed,Strongly Agree,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Neutral,Strongly Disagree,Strongly Agree,Agree
column2:
I believe generative AI has its pros, especially when used correctly; I believe that it should be seen as a tool. Anyone can use this tool, but in order to really benefit from it, you need to have a foundation in the knowledge you are asking for. For example, I will not fully grasp and "learn" how to code with zero prior experience if I ask ChatGPT to explain to me how to create a specific script that can read and write files. I will not be able to then apply this knowledge in other aspects of coding or even pass the information along. However, I believe if you are a student who has a good foundation in coding, you may find generative AI beneficial for those niche questions you can rapidly answer that will refresh you, for example you forgot where to find a specific prompt.

Sorry for the long paragraph, I am excited for this course!

genai: Some,Some,Disagree,Neutral,Allowed in some assignments\, disallowed in others (based on the assignment type\, course level\, etc.),Agree,Disagree,Disagree,Disagree,Agree,Disagree,Neutral,Neutral
column2: I think Gen AI can be a really useful and powerful tool but in academic/coursework settings there can be a lot of grey area so I tend to avoid it for research and writing. In general I don't think it is sustainably ethical and I don't enjoy the increasing prevalence and reliance on AI in academic settings and in day to day life due the large environmental impacts and blurry ethics. That being said when it comes to coding it can be a very useful tool from my personal experience. However I'm not very well versed in the ethics of coding hence why I answered neutral to the previous questions about whether copying code verbatim is ethical. I'm excited to learn more in this course and discuss AI further because I find it very fascinating!
